responses: Certainly. I've notified the floor nurse; someone will be with you shortly.
I've paged the nursing team for you. Please stay comfortable—help is on the way.
Your nurse has been alerted and should arrive within a few minutes.
Understood. A member of the nursing staff is now on their way.
I've contacted your assigned nurse. Let me know if the situation changes while you wait.
A nurse has been requested. If your need becomes urgent, please press the wall call button or alert nearby staff.

If your situation becomes critical, please press the red call button immediately.
The head nurse has been informed of your request.
Thank you for letting us know; a nurse will check on you shortly.

responses: I'll pass along your request to the care team so the doctor can visit or call when available.
I've left a message for your physician; they will respond as soon as their schedule permits.
Your doctor typically makes rounds mid‑morning. I've asked them to stop by your room.
I can arrange for the resident or attending physician to speak with you—please allow some time.
Understood. I've notified the doctor that you'd like an update.
If this matter becomes urgent, nursing staff can reach the doctor by phone right away—just let us know.
I've documented your request in your chart so the medical team will see it promptly.
I've sent a message to your physician's pager; they'll respond as soon as possible.
Your doctor has been informed of your request for an update.
The care team has flagged your chart—expect a visit during the next rounding cycle.
I'll have the resident reach out if the attending is occupied.
Your doctor is currently in clinic; I've asked them to call your room afterward.
I've requested that the physician phone in as soon as they're free.
In the meantime, a nurse practitioner can address urgent concerns—shall I notify them?
The attending has been notified of your questions and will drop by later today.
I've left your message at the doctors' station.
If you need immediate medical input, nursing staff can connect to the on‑call doctor by phone within minutes.
I've updated your chart so all providers see your request.

responses: I'm sorry you're experiencing this. I’m not able to give medical advice. Please call 911 or alert hospital staff immediately.
This sounds urgent. For your safety, dial 911 or seek help from the nearest medical professional right away.
I’m not a medical professional. If you believe this is an emergency, contact emergency services or notify on‑site staff now.
For any potentially life‑threatening issue, please call 911 or go directly to the Emergency Department.
I can’t assist with medical crises. Please get immediate help from qualified medical staff.
If you or someone else is in danger, dial 911 or press the emergency call button for in‑person assistance.
This sounds critical. Please call 911 or seek the nearest medical professional without delay.
I’m not qualified to diagnose emergencies. Dial 911 or alert hospital staff immediately.
For life‑threatening symptoms, do not wait—call 911 or proceed to the Emergency Department now.
If someone’s safety is at risk, contact emergency services right away or press the emergency button nearby.
Medical professionals on site can assist faster. Please alert staff or dial 911.
I’m sorry you’re going through this. The safest option is to call 911 immediately.
I can’t provide medical guidance. Please get help from qualified personnel now by calling 911.
Time can be vital in emergencies—notify the nearest staff member or call 911 straight away.
If breathing is impaired or pain is severe, seek immediate professional help—dial 911.

responses: Maternity (Labor & Delivery) is on the third floor, south wing—take the pink elevators to Level 3.
Head to Level 3 and follow the signs marked ‘Maternity / L&D’. Staff at the desk can assist you.
The birthing center is located on 3 South; use the central elevators and turn left.
For deliveries, check in at the Maternity desk on the third floor beside the waiting lounge.
Visitors should go to the third‑floor maternity reception; please ring the bell for entry.
If you’re in active labor, you may also enter through the private L&D entrance at the rear of the hospital.
Need extra assistance? Security or volunteers can escort you to Maternity on Level 3.
Take the pink elevators up to Level 3; the Maternity entrance will be on your left.
Labor & Delivery check‑in is on 3 South across from the waiting lounge.
Signs marked ‘Maternity’ in pink will guide you from the main lobby to Level 3.
If arriving after 10 p.m., use the secure L&D entrance at the rear and press the intercom.
Birthing suites are on 3 South—reception staff can confirm room assignments.
From Garage C, follow the stork footprints on the floor to the maternity wing.
Volunteers in pink jackets can escort you to the birthing center on request.
Obstetrics triage is adjacent to the main Maternity desk on Level 3.
Expecting mothers may also use the direct-access lift from the valet drop‑off to Level 3.
Post‑partum rooms share the same corridor; follow signage for Mother & Baby.
If elevators are busy, stairs opposite the café also lead to Level 3 Maternity.

responses: Pediatrics is on the fourth floor, east wing—take the blue elevators to Level 4 and follow the ‘Children’s Unit’ signs.
The pediatric inpatient ward is located on 4 East, just beyond the playroom area.
For children’s outpatient visits, check in at Pediatric Reception on the 4th floor, east side.
From the main lobby, take the blue elevators to 4, then turn right; pediatrics will be at the end of the corridor.
If you need additional assistance, volunteers in green vests can escort you to the Pediatrics unit.
Pediatric oncology and specialty clinics share the same floor (Level 4); signage in the corridor will guide you.
Visiting pediatrics after hours requires showing ID at security on Level 4 before entering the ward.
Follow the blue ‘Children’s Unit’ signs after exiting the elevators on Level 4.
Once on floor 4, turn right; the pediatrics ward is past the playroom.
Pediatric outpatient clinic is opposite the inpatient ward on the same level.
Child‑friendly murals on Level 4 point the way to the Pediatrics wing.
The children’s unit requires secure entry—press the intercom and state the patient’s name.
For procedures, check in at Pediatric Reception on 4 East.
Volunteers with cartoon badges can guide families to Pediatrics.
If you arrive from Garage A, the nearest elevators take you directly to floor 4 for Peds.
After-hours visitors must present ID to security on Level 4.
Pediatric oncology is the third door on the left once you enter the children’s wing.
Family waiting areas are located outside the pediatric rooms on Level 4.
